question: Cold. Careful with that. It's delicate equip... . . . ment.
answer: Yes. Very.

question: It's for protection. I deal in antique....
answer: I know what you deal in. And these? Your pajamas?

question: For jogging. My doctor's recommended five miles a...
answer: Sit down and shut it. Let's see the passport. What's your nationality this week, Templar?

question: I forget.
answer: Issued by the Principality of.. . Yemen? You're bloody joking.

question: Call the embassy
answer: Shut it. You pass through Russia for a day with that gear and, what a surprise, a prototype computer chip worth quarter of a billion quid is nicked from the Myaki Corporation the night you arrive. We know you didn't fence it in Russia. Where is it?

question: You've got three options
answer: What's the third.

question: You can kiss my ass. I'm a busy man. Make up your mind.
answer: .. . then me mum says, call uncle Charlie, he's in the airline business, there's jobs there, good benefits too, and.. ..where was I?

question: How you got your job.
answer: Right! 'Scuze me.

question: Another round please.
answer: Ye're tryin' ta get me drunk, aren't you? Are you cute or what? I gotta freshen up. Where's the loo in 'ere?

question: Back there. Leave your locket. I'll polish it for you.
answer: Are you a dearheart or what... Maam, where's the gent who was sitting 'ere? What?

question: Thanks Harry. Oh, and Harry... .. . ship this by overnight courier to that address. Yes. It depends. Involving what? Harry, I'm going for a walk over Blackfriars Bridge. Midnight.
answer: Interesting. You are not a big man. But men like you never are. It is my pleasure, Simon Templar. My name is...

question: I know who you are. Tell me what you want, or I keep walking.
answer: Suppose I don't want anything. Suppose I want to kill you.

question: Suppose there's a high-powered rifle trained at your head.
answer: Rumour has not lied about you, Mr. Templar. Last night something was stolen in St. Petersburg. My city.

question: You talk about the place as if you own it.
answer: I do, Mr. Templar. May I ask who hired you?

question: You can ask. I won't answer.
answer: What you stole I wanted very badly. Ilya. What is the saying - if you can't beat them, why not join them? An American phrase, no? Or are you British? Australian?

question: I'm nothing. Except bored. Get to the point.
answer: Of course. An American scientist has worked ten years to develop a certain technology. I am informed that the technology will be made public at the annual nuclear science symposium in Washington D.C. I would like the plans and specifications for this technology. Before the symposium.

question: What are we talking about?
answer: A nuclear fusion generator. We have a man on the inside.

question: Why can't he steal it?
answer: He's tried. The scientist trusts no one and keeps no hard records of the technology in the lab.

question: Nuclear fusion. They say it's mankind's only hope after all the oil's gone. This guy's actually done it?
answer: She.

question: Come again?
answer: She, Mr. Templar. The scientist is a woman. Her dossier. All the information you will need.

question: My fee is fifteen million U.S. dollars, half up front, half when I deliver. You'll hear from me.
answer: Templar, one question. I ask you to steal a person's entire life's work. You have no reaction. Are you that cold? No, rumor hasn't lied about you, Templar.

question: Filtered water, high fructose corn syrup. Lemon juice concentrate. Citric acid. Gum acacia...? Totally natural, yeah right.
answer: Try this. Sorry, I overheard. The real thing. No chemicals, no preservatives.

question: Thanks.
answer: Hello again. These aren't ripe. How are the apples?

question: Excellent. They're in season.
answer: I wonder why He didn't want us to eat these.

question: Who?
answer: God. In the Garden of Eden.

question: Oh right. Sorry, little slow today. Bad headache. Uhm, actually, I don't know.
answer: Why wasn't it

question: Sorry. Can't help you.
answer: How about William Tell? You really think he shot one of these off his brother's head with an arrow?

question: Do I know you?
answer: Unlikely. I just moved to New York.

question: Well uhhm, sir, to answer your apple questions, one, I don't know what God's problem was. Two, William Tell, like Paul Bunyon, never existed. And in case you're wondering, Isaac Newton discovered gravity through planetary observation not because one of those fell on his head, and I seriously doubt that eating one a day will keep the doctor away. Okay? By the way - welcome to the Big Apple. No, really? Moron. C'mon, Dr. Singh. Tell me something I don't know. Just keep driving.
answer: Hello! She walks up to him. Together they look down at THE REAR TIRE. It's flat, a pancake.

question: Where's the spare?
answer: I.. .well.. .I'm not really certain.

question: You do know how to change a tire.
answer: Sorry. I'm not very... mechanical.

question: Give me your keys.
answer: Sorry.

question: All right, where do you live?
answer: Close.

question: It's your lucky day. Come on. Try room temperature, idiot. The Tokamak's got it all backwards.
answer: Uhhm. Excuse me. Who is that?

question: Him? A powerful, well-respected man who doesn't know a goddarnn thing what he's talking about. If I got one tenth of his funding...
answer: It's the next left. First driveway on the right.

question: You live here? Are you for real?
answer: Like the label says. No chemicals, no preservatives.

question: You work for this or inherit it?
answer: My father made shoes. I inherited the company. Now I make shoes.

question: That's a helluva lot of shoes.
answer: Uhm listen, I'm not very good at this and I realize we just met, but I'm even-tempered, politically moderate, belong to no religious cults, have no children I know of, am free of communicable diseases, I happen to find you attractive...

question: Wait a minute, hold on. Are you asking me out on a date?
answer: Yes.

question: How do you know I'm not married?
answer: I believe the fourth finger on your left hand is...

question: Okay so I'm not married. I could have a boyfriend.
answer: I'd be surprised if you didn't have several.

question: Be surprised. Lemme give you a hand. What about you? There's no wife stashed on some island someplace?
answer: No wife stashed on some island.

question: No mistress? C'mon. No bimbo on the side?
answer: Not a one.

question: Well, that's a start. Here's the deal with me
answer: Michael. Michael Quinn.

question: I'm Jillian St. Thomas. I'll give you my number.
answer: Just say it. I have a good memory.

question: Eight seven seven, five two nine eight.
answer: Good. Great. I'll call you.

question: I've heard that before.
answer: I will call you. You saved me today. Thanks again.

question: Hey. What's my number?
answer: Eight seven seven, five two nine eight.

question: And he has a brain. What do you know.
answer: I am not eccentric.

question: No? You live in the biggest house in America but do your own shopping, you talk to strange women about the history of apples, and you give a first-time date.. . shoes? Isn't the tradition flowers?
answer: You said you liked them.

question: I do. I'm joking. They're beautiful. Thank-you. What happened?
answer: Just the check please. You didn't answer my question. Maybe it made you uncomfortable. Maybe I should just shut up...

question: No, it's all right. Okay
answer: Canada.

question: I don't know what it's like there, but here, if a teenage girl doesn't want to be a cheerleader, or drink 'till she pukes every weekend, or talk endlessly on the phone every night about absolutely nothing, then she doesn't win many popularity contests, know what I mean? That pretty much took care of highschool.
answer: College?

question: Try earning double p.h.d.'s from Harvard before you turn twenty-three and having a social life.
answer: Can I ask a personal question? What's your I.Q.?

question: That's personal? My I.Q.? Let's just say it's high.
answer: Very high.

question: Yes, very high. As high as yours.
answer: You don't honestly mean that.

question: Oh, you're a smart one, shoemaker. It's in the eyes. I can always tell. I just don't often get the opportunity. It feels nice.
answer: For me, too. You're very pretty.

question: Stop it. Flattery will get you... someplace. I don't know where yet.
answer: No no no, absolutely not. Put that away.

question: It's not for us. It's for the couple over there. Waiter, put their bill on my card please. I'll make the booze. Turn on the news. I want to catch up on that Russia thing.
answer: Scotch please. No ice.

question: What brand? That country's going to explode.
answer: It very well might. Oban.

question: What? .
answer: My brand of scotch. Oban. Have any?

question: No, but there's a liquor store five minutes away.
answer: Wait. Don't be ridiculous.

question: I want to be ridiculous. Michael, I haven't had anybody over in...a long time. And I happen to like you. I want to do this right. Okay? I'll be back in ten minutes. Build a fire.
answer: You're making this too easy, dear. Smart girl. Send your data into cyberspace and only you can retrieve it. Because only you have the code.

question: Night, Walter.
answer: Okay, think. Think.

question: Try room temperature, idiot. The Tokamak's got it all backwards.
answer: Open sesame. That was quick.

question: Now Mr. Michael Quinn, let's have that scotch. Hey, what happened to the fire?
answer: I thought we'd create our own.

question: Down boy. Whoah whoah whoah, time to put on the brakes. Those lips oughtta be licensed buddy...
answer: Sorry. I wasn't trying to...

question: I know you weren't but if we keep going I'm gonna be the one who gets us both in trouble. Whew! Haven't felt like that for awhile. Am I going to see you again? Michael?
answer: How about breakfast?

question: It's a date. I'll walk you out, shoemaker.
answer: Good-night.

question: There's a problem. This is the data your thief sent us.
answer: Cold fusion?

question: Yes. Fusion at room temperature. Regarded as an impossibility by the scientific community. A myth. Then I read this. She first proves why hot fusion - the tokamak - is impractical. You must heat the hydrogen gases so high, more energy is wasted than created. Here she goes into the benefits of cold fusion. The hydrogen isotopes needed. The physical plant. She even estimates its cost. Extraordinary. The next pages are the critical part, what no one in fifty years has discovered. The combination of chemicals in which atoms will fuse at room temperature.
answer: Well? Let's see.

question: Tretiak - I think from reading this that the woman's done it. She may have found a source of unlimited energy.
answer: What do you mean may have. Show me.

question: I said there was a problem. Zubov hits the "scroll" key. The next page appears; we see the heading at the top of the page
answer: Where's the rest of it?

question: Yes. Sure. Black please. Thanks. Excuse me, that's my. . . . That's a Reuger nine shot. I counted nine.
answer: What if you're wrong.

question: When were you hired and for what?
answer: Okay. Take it easy. I was hired a week ago to take you and the woman out, and detonate the house. It was empty when I got here.

question: Who's your employer?
answer: I don't ask names.

question: Did they have accents? Russian? I'm paying you out of your contract. Don't ask questions. What's your price?
answer: Fifty thousand for you, fifty for her, fifty for the house.

question: U.S. bearer bonds. Good as cash.
answer: About the airport - no offense you understand.

question: None taken. Go and don't come back. A. . . .plane. Indeed, Simon Templar, a plane. Your ticket. What'd you pay for it? I'll give you twenty grand for it. Cash. Right now. I need to get on that plane.
answer: Merci, Coco. Remy Samarkand Aeronautique, Remy Samarkand. Anything for Simon Templar...

question: IT'S A LITTLE JET, MAYBE A TURBO What are you smuggling these days?
answer: Oh, things. How long has it been  two year? Three? Now tell me

question: Fifteen million dollars of my money. And a score to settle.
answer: Ja. Simon? Where are you?

question: Unimportant. How soon can you be in St. Petersburg?
answer: Five hours. What type of job?

question: Eyes and ears. Two hundred thousand cash for two days work.
answer: Who's the mark?

question: Gregor Tretiak. His headquarters. His office in particular.
answer: Gregor Tretiak is not a very nice man, Simon. Four hundred thousand.

question: The St. Petersburg tower wants us to circle.
answer: No. Follow them down.

question: What do we do when we land?
answer: Haven't figured that out yet.

question: Put down in Helsinki and wait for my call!
answer: Help me. I'm American. Police!

question: Sorry about this.
answer: Do you speak English? Thank God. I'm an American scientist. Last night, in New York, a man stole something from me, then this morning I was kidnapped by my lab assistant, god this sounds like a bad novel . . . . . What was that? What...? WHO...?

question: Help them!
answer: Who are you. Tell me who you are and what the hell is going on.

question: I was hired to steal your research, but you know that by now. You left the critical data off the disk. Where is it? memorized, right? That's a bad cut. Here. Look, you're in big trouble. The guy who hired me will do anything to get your research. Once he has it, you're a corpse. Give me the missing data and I'll get you out of here. You can trust me.
answer: Trust you? Trust you...?

question: Get on a plane. Leave tonight.
answer: This had better be important. It's my wife's birthday.

question: My apologies to your wife.
answer: An apology from Tretiak? An historic moment.

question: Come now, Ivan, why must we feud.
answer: We feud because we hate each other.

question: It is true there have been harsh words between us. We are rivals. But rivalry is bad for business. Upon what conditions would you accept a partnership? Be reasonable.
answer: Fifty percent of the drug trade in St. Petersburg and Moscow. A third of prostitution and gambling.

question: Agreed. I need the men in your areas, Ivan, for two days. Particularly Moscow and points South.
answer: Why?

question: To find this woman... and kill this man.
answer: This is a private matter, I take it. Then you'll have them.

question: Ilya - some wine for Ivan Gracha.
answer: What is this, Tretiak?

question: Call you later, Frankie. We're going to jump. Okay? You can't get rid of me.
answer: Like a bad flu.

question: Pretty smart, selling the clothes and watch. You were going for the U.S. embassy, weren't you?
answer: Present tense please  I am going. Before we discuss the present, let's discuss the past. Who the hell are you. I want full name, address, profession, and don't - don't - say Michael Quinn of 112 Mason Street, shoemaker.

question: My name is Simon Templar. I don't have an address because I live in hotels. I'm a professional thief.
answer: Good. We're getting somewhere. I'd like to respond to that. You wicked man. Thief. I hope you rot in hell.

question: Where are you going?
answer: As far away from you as I can.

question: Sit down.
answer: You're joking.

question: I need to use the ladies' room. I think you can trust me to...
answer: I don't trust anybody.

question: Tell me something. How much were you paid?
answer: It's not your business. Move.

question: I think it is. C'mon. Tell me.
answer: Fifteen million dollars, but it didn't work out. Did it.

question: Does it bother you? What you do?
answer: No.

question: You have no conscience? No sense of morality?
answer: Define morality.

question: It's a commonly used and generally understood word.
answer: Not by me. . Wait.

question: You are not going in there with me. Okay, how about
answer: How about

question: How about
answer: The man who said that was crucified by his.

question: Were you raised by wolves? Who were your parents, Lucretia Borgia and the Marquis de Sader
answer: The two people in question weren't as nice as that. I wouldn't know. I never met them. Are you through? It's all yours.

question: International operator please. The American Embassy in Moscow, please. You really will rot in hell, know that?
answer: Good, all my friends will be waiting for me. They move down the aisle, passing the SERVING PORTER, Jillian's hand dangles over the fruit and cheese cart. She plucks up a SERVING KNIFE with two fingers and slides it up her sleeve.

question: Friends? I thought you trusted no one.
answer: I don't. Give it to me.

question: What.
answer: The knife you just took.

question: I'm so sorry! Give me a second, will you? I don't feel well.
answer: Make it quick.

question: Just a second. Yes.
answer: John Whitehead, Special Agent, Central Intelligence Agency. Was your trip all right?

question: Yes it was fine, oh who cares, I'm finally safe... Do you have a car?
answer: Yes, outside. First I'd like to ask you some questions. That was an interesting story you told the embassy.

question: Interesting? It's true.
answer: Please understand

question: Talk to me, Frankie.
answer: She called the U.S. Embassy a half hour ago.

question: What? Does Tretiak know?
answer: Simon, the U.S. Embassy has more leaks than a Polish submarine. Who do you think intercepted the call?

question: Thanks, Frankie.
answer: Simon, wait. . . .

question: . ..Cd, that's big "C" little "d," cadmium's valence is 2, its atomic number is 48 and its atomic weight is 112.411 or would you like that carried out five more decimal places? Good enough?
answer: Good enough. Come this way, Ms. St. Thomas. He ushers her off.

question: What a nightmare.. To think my work could just be taken from me...
answer: You're safe now, Doctor St. Thomas. We'll have you back in New York in no time. They continue toward the parked Mercedes.

question: Agent Whitehead... Nothing, I was just thinking that when my research was stolen I felt like the Buffalo Bills after they lost four World Series.
answer: Hah hah, I bet you did. I'm a baseball fan too hah hah...

question: The embassy's surrounded. The airport's out. They're drawing a noose around us. We don't have much time.
answer: What are you going to do? Tell me. I deserve at least that. I'll die. If you take their offer, they'll kill me.

question: And if I don't, they'll kill me. Interesting situation I'd say.
answer: Oh god. It's over, it's all over... You're not human. You're an animal.

question: I'm a businessman. I perform services for profit. And spare me the lecture. You didn't spend ten years in that mildewed basement for the good of humanity, you did it to get rich. Richer than anyone on earth. Richer than God. I'll make you an offer - pay me my fifteen million out of your royalties - should come to about one month's. . .
answer: I don't hold the patent rights to cold fusion.

question: What?
answer: You fool. Don't you understand? It wasn't about money, it wasn't about becoming rich...

question: If you don't own the patent rights, who does?
answer: A foundation in my name. The royalties were going to go to scientific research, curing cancer, .. .christ how can you understand this...

question: That's a municipal water main. In one hour you're going in there. Listen. They shut it down twice a day for five minutes to clean the filters. Once at noon, once at midnight. Noon is in one hour.
answer: How do you know all this?

question: Part of my job. Now ask the logical question...
answer: .. . where does it go?

question: Very good. Under the United States Embassy. There's an exit hatch into the embassy courtyard. That's where we're going.
You heard me.
answer: Then what happens?

question: Let's get to the embassy, then we'll talk about it.
answer: Templar - about that night at my house

question: Don't talk about it, okay?
answer: Okay.

question: Right on time. Four blocks. Right under Tretiak's men and up into the embassy compound. You can do this. She grabs Templar's hand. He pulls her up and inside --
answer: It doesn't seem like we've gone far enough.

question: We haven't, up there's the street in front of the embassy. Come on. We've got two minutes. There it is.
answer: Oh my god... We. ...we've got to go back.

question: Not enough time. The hatch under the street.
answer: What about Tretiak's men

question: Better than drowning.
answer: The water's back on!

question: City gas line.
answer: We can't stay here, we'll asphyxiate.

question: Both of us will never make it. But one of us can. Give me ten seconds, then break for the embassy and don't stop running until you're at the gates. It's a hundred yards, so move it.
answer: What are you going to...

question: That's my business.
answer: Wait... .. .Simon. Don't do this. They'll kill you.

question: Open the gate!
answer: Do it.

question: I'm an American citizen.
answer: You have our full protection ma'am. Back away from the gate.

question: Do something!
answer: That's Russian soil out there, ma'am.

question: No. No. No. I'm certain. It's not him. They showed me photographs of criminals. And a photograph of you.
answer: And...?

question: I said that the man in the photograph doesn't have the eyes of a criminal. The Washington symposium is tomorrow afternoon. I'm going. I'm presenting my research to the scientific community.
answer: What about your data...

question: It's in my head. I'll wing it.
answer: You need to conduct further research anyway. I'll help you.

question: What are we researching. ..?
answer: The benefits of warm fusion.

question: It is in the eyes. You're not bad.
answer: Being bad is the only thing I've ever been good at.

question: You can be good at being good. If you're afraid of the dark, remember the night rainbow. If tomorrow morning the sky falls, have clouds for breakfast. If the birds forget their songs, listen to the wind. And if between right and wrong, do what is right.
answer: Who said that?

question: My grandmother.
answer: How did I meet you. This saint. Saint Thomas.

question: That question will be answered in ten minutes, Mr. Rothstein. Sorry, but I'm not interested in Doctor Singh's opinions on this or anything else. Please, no more questions. ... Stop it! I know him! Simon? What is it?
answer: Are you all right?

question: Yes. Go get a seat. Good afternoon. In 1989, two physicists claimed to have perfected... .. .cold nuclear fusion. Their results couldn't be duplicated. ... It is my pleasure to announce that
answer: JILLIAN!! ! No. No. No... AMBULANCE, GET AN AMBULANCE!

question: Simon... I love you... My Saint. . . . .
answer: No. . . No. . . God please no... But God won't help you, Simon Templar... ...God will take her anyway.

question: A nuclear bunker, Mr. President? You must worry for your safety.
answer: I have reason to.

question: Yes. You do.
answer: You understand my policy on taping meetings. I'll get to the point. Your remarks are irresponsible; they've caused civil unrest. Unless you appeal to your supporters to stop rioting, I will institute martial law. Tell me what you want.

question: A public debate, then new elections. We'll let the people decide.
answer: Agreed.

question: The woman's death was unfortunate. You lost. I lost. To think what we could have done with her formula. But life goes on, no? When Romanov gains the presidency Russia will be ours. The possibilities are, you would agree, endless. You have talent. Unique talent. I need that talent to break into an impregnable facility. Be part of this, Templar.
answer: Fifteen million, plus the fifteen you owe me.

question: I owe you nothing. You were hired to steal something and you failed.
answer: Thirty million, and I use my own men.

question: Twenty million, and one of my men goes with you. Templar. A question. You had feelings for the woman, didn't you?
answer: I don't have feelings, Tretiak.

question: Electronic by-pass?
answer: Negative. Understand something, Simon, please

question: What's that?
answer: Uhhm.. .that is the facility's... ... radiation detector. In the event of nuclear fall-out it automatically closes the hatch.

question: You're saying the system can think.
answer: Yes.

question: Friends, countrymen, I give you Major Antonin Scarpinin.
answer: Thank you for coming, Ivan, it is a great night for Russia. Maybe you should take greater interest in politics, Ivan Gracha. Tretiak and Gracha turn to Major Scarpinin, listening...

question: One month ago I said I would prove that those who call themselves our leaders... .. .are in league with those who we know to be thieves, traitors, rapists of our once-great country. Do you want to see this proof?
answer: Hail Michael Romanov, Czar of the Fatherland. How will that sound to the average Russian?

question: The average Russian is a fool. He exists to be dominated. To partnership in government.
answer: No Romanov  to partnership in crime.

question: We can share this, Templar.
answer: We don't own it.

question: Who does?
answer: The Jillian St. Thomas Foundation.

question: Don't be a fool.
answer: I'm a fool? You thought you could get away with murder. Used curare didn't you? Induces blood-clotting.

question: What do you want?
answer: What do I want? I want.. . revenge. Now give me the disk.
